This change made the Gregorian calendar more accurate and prevented the calendar from drifting further out of sync with the seasons.

* **(D) The Julian calendar's leap year rules were too complex, leading to an inconsistent year length.** The Julian calendar's leap year rules were simple: every four years was a leap year. The issue was the slight overestimation of the year's length, not the complexity of the rules.

